<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Arial,sans-serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE GOLDMAN SACHS GROUP, INC. and SUBSIDIARIES</B>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 10px"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-left: 2.5%"><B><I>Deferrable Interest Junior Subordinated Debentures</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">In February&nbsp;2004, Goldman Sachs
Capital&nbsp;I (the Trust), a wholly owned Delaware statutory trust,
was formed by the firm for the exclusive purposes of (i)&nbsp;issuing
$2.75&nbsp;billion of guaranteed preferred beneficial
interests and $85&nbsp;million of common beneficial interests in the
Trust, (ii)&nbsp;investing the proceeds from the sale to purchase
junior subordinated debentures from Group Inc. and (iii)&nbsp;engaging
in only those other activities necessary or incidental to
these purposes. The preferred beneficial interests were purchased
by third parties, and, as of November&nbsp;2004, the firm held all of
the common beneficial interests.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The Trust is a wholly owned finance
subsidiary of the firm for legal and regulatory purposes. However,
for accounting purposes, under FIN&nbsp;No.&nbsp;46-R, the Trust is
not a consolidated subsidiary of the firm because the firm&#146;s
ownership of the common beneficial interest is not considered at
risk, since the Trust&#146;s principal asset is the $2.84&nbsp;billion of
junior subordinated debentures issued by the firm. The firm pays
interest semiannually on these debentures at an annual rate of
6.345% and the debentures mature on February&nbsp;15, 2034. The
coupon rate and payment dates applicable to the beneficial
interests are the same as the interest rate and payment dates
applicable to the debentures. See Note&nbsp;6 for further
information regarding the firm&#146;s guarantee of the preferred
beneficial interests issued by the Trust.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The firm has the right, from time to
time, to defer payment of interest on the junior subordinated
debentures, and, therefore, cause payment of dividends on the
Trust&#146;s preferred beneficial interests to be deferred, in each case
for up to ten consecutive semiannual periods, and during any such
extension period Group Inc. will not be permitted to, among other
things, pay dividends on or make certain repurchases of its common
stock. The Trust is not permitted to pay any distributions on the
common beneficial interests held by the firm unless all dividends
payable on the preferred beneficial interests have been paid in
full.

<DIV align="left">
<A name="321"></A>
</DIV>
<!-- link1 "Note 6. Commitments, Contingencies and Guarantees" -->

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; background: transparent; color: #000000">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap width="5%"><B>Note&nbsp;6.</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="94%"><B>Commitments, Contingencies and Guarantees</B></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-left: 2.5%"><B><I>Commitments</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The firm had commitments to enter
into forward secured financing transactions, including certain
repurchase and resale agreements and secured borrowing and lending
arrangements, of $48.32&nbsp;billion and $35.25&nbsp;billion as of
November&nbsp;2004 and November&nbsp;2003, respectively.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">In connection with its lending
activities, the firm had outstanding commitments of $27.72&nbsp;billion
and $15.83&nbsp;billion as of November&nbsp;2004 and November
2003, respectively. The firm&#146;s commitments to extend credit are
agreements to lend to counterparties that have fixed termination
dates and are contingent on all conditions to borrowing set forth
in the contract having been met. Since these commitments may expire
unused, the total commitment amount does not necessarily reflect
the actual future cash flow requirements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">As of November&nbsp;2004 and November
2003, $9.40&nbsp;billion and $4.32&nbsp;billion, respectively, of the
firm&#146;s outstanding commitments to extend credit have been issued
through the William Street credit extension program. These
commitments were primarily issued through William Street Commitment
Corporation (Commitment Corp), a consolidated wholly owned
subsidiary of Group Inc. Another consolidated wholly owned
subsidiary, William Street Funding Corporation (Funding Corp), was
formed to raise funding to support the William Street credit
extension program. Commitment Corp and Funding Corp are each
separate corporate entities, with assets and liabilities that are
legally separated from the other assets and liabilities of the
firm. Accordingly, the assets of Commitment Corp and of Funding
Corp will not be available to their respective shareholders until
the claims of their respective creditors have been paid. In
addition, no affiliate of either Commitment Corp or


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">117</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Arial,sans-serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE GOLDMAN SACHS GROUP, INC. and SUBSIDIARIES</B>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 10px"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</B>
</DIV>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">Funding Corp, except in limited cases as expressly agreed in writing, is
responsible for any obligation of either entity. Substantially all
of the credit risk associated with these commitments has been
covered by credit loss protection provided to the firm by SMFG. The
firm has also hedged the credit risk of certain non-William Street
commitments using a variety of other financial instruments.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The firm provides letters of credit
issued by various banks to counterparties in lieu of securities or
cash to satisfy various collateral and margin deposit requirements.
Letters of credit outstanding were $11.15&nbsp;billion and $12.60&nbsp;billion
as of November&nbsp;2004 and November&nbsp;2003, respectively.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The firm acts as an investor in
merchant banking transactions, which includes making long-term
investments in equity and debt securities in privately negotiated
transactions, corporate acquisitions and real estate transactions.
In connection with these activities, the firm had commitments to
invest up to $1.04&nbsp;billion and $1.38&nbsp;billion in corporate
and real estate investment funds as of November&nbsp;2004 and November
2003, respectively.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The firm had construction-related
commitments of $107&nbsp;million and $87&nbsp;million as of November&nbsp;2004
and November&nbsp;2003, respectively, and other purchase
commitments of $242&nbsp;million and $255&nbsp;million as of November
2004 and November&nbsp;2003, respectively.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">As of November&nbsp;2004, the firm had
entered into a contract to acquire interests in power plants and
related businesses from National Energy&nbsp;&#038; Gas Transmission,
Inc., including additional interests in some of the same power
plants and a natural gas pipeline in which Cogentrix Energy, Inc.,
a wholly owned subsidiary of the firm, already holds interests, for
approximately $550&nbsp;million.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The firm has contractual obligations
under long-term noncancelable lease agreements, principally for
office space, expiring on various dates through 2029. Certain
agreements are subject to periodic escalation provisions for
increases in real estate taxes and other charges. Future minimum
rental payments, net of minimum sublease rentals, and rent charged
to operating expense for the last three years are set forth below:

</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-left: 2.5%"><B><I>Contingencies</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The firm is involved in a number of
judicial, regulatory and arbitration proceedings concerning matters
arising in connection with the conduct of its businesses.
Management believes, based on currently available information, that
the results of such proceedings, in the aggregate, will not have a
material adverse effect on the firm&#146;s financial condition, but may
be material to the firm&#146;s operating results for any particular
period, depending, in part, upon the operating results for such
period. Given the inherent difficulty of predicting the outcome of
the firm&#146;s litigation matters, particularly in cases in


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">118</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Arial,sans-serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE GOLDMAN SACHS GROUP, INC. and SUBSIDIARIES</B>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 10px"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</B>
</DIV>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">which claimants seek substantial or indeterminate damages, the firm
cannot estimate losses or ranges of losses for cases where there is
only a reasonable possibility that a loss may have been incurred.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-left: 2.5%"><B><I>Guarantees</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The firm enters into various
derivative contracts that meet the definition of a guarantee under
FIN&nbsp;No.&nbsp;45. Such derivative contracts include credit
default swaps, written equity and commodity put options, written
currency contracts and interest rate caps, floors and swaptions. FIN&nbsp;No.&nbsp;45
does not require disclosures about derivative
contracts if such contracts may be cash settled and the firm has no
basis to conclude it is probable that the counterparties held, at
inception, the underlying instruments related to the derivative
contracts. The firm has concluded that these conditions have been
met, for certain large, internationally active commercial and
investment bank end users and certain other users. Accordingly, the
firm has not included such contracts in the tables below.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The firm, in its capacity as an
agency lender, occasionally indemnifies securities lending
customers against losses incurred in the event that borrowers do
not return securities and the collateral held is insufficient to
cover the market value of the securities borrowed. In relation to
certain asset sales and securitization transactions, the firm
guarantees the collection of contractual cash flows. In connection
with its merchant banking activities, the firm may issue loan
guarantees to secure financing and to obtain preferential terms. In
addition, the firm provides letters of credit and other guarantees,
on a limited basis, to enable clients to enhance their credit
standing and complete transactions.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">In connection with the firm&#146;s
establishment of the Trust, Group Inc. effectively provided for the
full and unconditional guarantee of the beneficial interests in the
Trust held by third parties. Timely payment by Group Inc. of
interest on the junior subordinated debentures and other amounts
due and performance of its other obligations under the transaction
documents will be sufficient to cover payments due by the Trust on
its beneficial interests. As a result, management believes that it
is unlikely the firm will have to make payments related to the
Trust other than those required under the junior subordinated
debentures and in connection with certain expenses incurred by the
Trust.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">119</DIV>

    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left"><SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: top;">(3)</SUP></TD>

losses in connection with these contracts.</TD>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">In the normal course of its business,
the firm indemnifies and guarantees certain service providers, such
as clearing and custody agents, trustees and administrators,
against specified potential losses in connection with their acting
as an agent of, or providing services to, the firm or its
affiliates. The firm also indemnifies some clients against
potential losses incurred in the event


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">120</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Arial,sans-serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE GOLDMAN SACHS GROUP, INC. and SUBSIDIARIES</B>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 10px"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</B>
</DIV>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">specified third-party service providers, including subcustodians and third-party brokers,
improperly execute transactions. In addition, the firm is a member
of payment, clearing and settlement networks as well as securities
exchanges around the world that may require the firm to meet the
obligations of such networks and exchanges in the event of member
defaults. In connection with its prime brokerage and clearing
businesses, the firm may agree to clear and settle on behalf of its
clients the transactions entered into by them with other brokerage
firms. The firm&#146;s obligations in respect of such transactions are
secured by the assets in the client&#146;s account as well as any
proceeds received from the transactions cleared and settled by the
firm on behalf of the client. In connection with joint venture
investments, the firm may issue loan guarantees under which it may
be liable in the event of fraud, misappropriation, environmental
liabilities and certain other matters involving the borrower. The
firm is unable to develop an estimate of the maximum payout under
these guarantees and indemnifications. However, management believes
that it is unlikely the firm will have to make material payments
under these arrangements, and no liabilities related to these
guarantees and indemnifications have been recognized in the
consolidated statements of financial condition as of November&nbsp;2004
and November&nbsp;2003.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The firm provides representations and
warranties to counterparties in connection with a variety of
commercial transactions and occasionally indemnifies them against
potential losses caused by the breach of those representations and
warranties. The firm may also provide indemnifications protecting
against changes in or adverse application of certain U.S.&nbsp;tax
laws in connection with ordinary-course transactions such as
securities issuances, borrowings or derivatives. In addition, the
firm may provide indemnifications to some counterparties to protect
them in the event additional taxes are owed or payments are
withheld, due either to a change in or an adverse application of
certain non-U.S.&nbsp;tax laws. These indemnifications generally are
standard contractual terms and are entered into in the normal
course of business. Generally, there are no stated or notional
amounts included in these indemnifications, and the contingencies
triggering the obligation to indemnify are not expected to occur.
The firm is unable to develop an estimate of the maximum payout
under these guarantees. However, management believes that it is
unlikely the firm will have to make material payments under these
arrangements, and no liabilities related to these arrangements have
been recognized in the consolidated statements of financial
condition as of November&nbsp;2004 and November&nbsp;2003.

<DIV align="left">
<A name="322"></A>
</DIV>
<!-- link1 "Note 7. Shareholders&#146; Equity" -->

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; background: transparent; color: #000000">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap width="5%"><B>Note&nbsp;7.</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="94%"><B>Shareholders&#146; Equity</B></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">Dividends declared per common share
were $1.00 in 2004, $0.74 in 2003 and $0.48 in 2002. On December&nbsp;15,
2004, the Board of Directors of Group Inc. (the Board)
declared a dividend of $0.25&nbsp;per share to be paid on February&nbsp;24,
2005 to common shareholders of record on January&nbsp;25,
&nbsp;2005.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">During 2004 and 2003, the firm
repurchased 18.7&nbsp;million shares and 12.2&nbsp;million shares of
the firm&#146;s common stock, respectively. The average price paid per
share for repurchased shares was $96.29 and $76.83 for the years
ended November&nbsp;2004 and November&nbsp;2003, respectively. In addition,
to satisfy minimum statutory employee tax withholding requirements
related to the delivery of shares underlying restricted stock
units, the firm cancelled 9.1&nbsp;million restricted stock units at
an average price of $95.20&nbsp;per unit in 2004. On January&nbsp;30,
2004, the Board authorized the repurchase of an additional 15.0&nbsp;million
shares of common stock pursuant to the firm&#146;s existing
repurchase program. As of November&nbsp;2004, the firm was authorized to
repurchase up to 6.4&nbsp;million additional shares of common stock
pursuant to the firm&#146;s repurchase program.

</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<A name="324"></A>
</DIV>
<!-- link1 "Note 9. Goodwill and Identifiable Intangible Assets" -->

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; background: transparent; color: #000000">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap width="5%"><B>Note&nbsp;9.</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="94%"><B>Goodwill and Identifiable Intangible Assets</B></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-left: 2.5%"><B><I>Goodwill</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">As of November&nbsp;2004 and November
2003, goodwill of $3.18&nbsp;billion and $3.16&nbsp;billion,
respectively, was included in &#147;Other assets&#148; in the consolidated
statements of financial condition.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">122</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<HR size="1" width="12%" align="left" noshade color="#000000" style="margin-left: 5%">
<DIV align="right">
<TABLE width="95%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 8pt">

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left"><SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: top;">(1)</SUP></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="98%">Primarily includes the firm&#146;s clearance and
execution and Nasdaq customer lists acquired in the
firm&#146;s combination with SLK LLC (SLK)&nbsp;and financial
counseling customer lists acquired in the firm&#146;s
combination with The Ayco Company, L.P.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 4pt">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left"><SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: top;">(2)</SUP></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="98%">Primarily includes technology-related assets
acquired in the firm&#146;s combination with SLK.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 4pt">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left"><SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: top;">(3)</SUP></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="98%">Gross carrying amount and accumulated
amortization exclude amounts related to assets that were
no longer in service at the beginning of the period.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 4pt">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left"><SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: top;">(4)</SUP></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="98%">Accumulated amortization includes $188&nbsp;million
of impairment charges primarily related to option
specialist rights.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">Identifiable intangible assets are
amortized over their estimated useful lives. The weighted average
remaining life of the firm&#146;s identifiable intangibles is
approximately 17&nbsp;years. There were no identifiable intangible
assets that were considered to be indefinite-lived and, therefore,
not subject to amortization.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">Amortization expense associated with
identifiable intangible assets was $125&nbsp;million, $319&nbsp;million
(including $188&nbsp;million of impairment charges) and $127&nbsp;million
for the fiscal years ended November&nbsp;2004, November
2003 and November&nbsp;2002, respectively.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">Estimated future amortization expense
for existing identifiable intangible assets is set forth below:

<DIV align="left">
<A name="326"></A>
</DIV>
<!-- link1 "Note 11. Employee Benefit Plans" -->

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; background: transparent; color: #000000">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap width="5%"><B>Note&nbsp;11.</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="94%"><B>Employee Benefit Plans</B></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The firm sponsors various pension
plans and certain other postretirement benefit plans, primarily
healthcare and life insurance, which cover most employees
worldwide. The firm also provides certain benefits to former or
inactive employees prior to retirement. A summary of these plans is
set forth below.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-left: 2.5%"><B><I>Defined Benefit Pension Plans and Postretirement Plans</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The firm maintains a defined benefit
pension plan for substantially all U.S.&nbsp;employees. As of
November&nbsp;2004, this plan has been closed to new participants and no
further benefits will be accrued to existing participants.
Employees of certain non-U.S.&nbsp;subsidiaries participate in
various local defined benefit plans. These plans generally provide
benefits based on years of credited service and a percentage of the
employee&#146;s eligible compensation. In addition, the firm has
unfunded postretirement benefit plans that provide medical and life
insurance for eligible retirees, employees and dependents in the
United States.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">124</DIV>

</DIV>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The accumulated benefit obligation
for all defined benefit plans was $742&nbsp;million and $560&nbsp;million
as of November&nbsp;2004 and November&nbsp;2003, respectively.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">For plans in which the accumulated
benefit obligation exceeded plan assets, the aggregate projected
benefit obligation and accumulated benefit obligation was $184&nbsp;million
and $154&nbsp;million, respectively, as of November&nbsp;2004,
and $160&nbsp;million and $139&nbsp;million, respectively, as of
November&nbsp;2003. The fair value of plan assets for each of these
plans was $104&nbsp;million and $97&nbsp;million as of November&nbsp;2004
and November&nbsp;2003, respectively.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">125</DIV>

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Arial,sans-serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE GOLDMAN SACHS GROUP, INC. and SUBSIDIARIES</B>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 10px"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</B>
</DIV>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The weighted average assumptions used
to develop net periodic pension cost and the actuarial present
value of the projected benefit obligation are set forth below.
These assumptions represent a weighted average of the assumptions
used for the U.S. and non-U.S.&nbsp;plans and are based on the
economic environment of each applicable country.

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="90%">
<!-- Begin Table Head --><TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="64%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD> </TD>
    <TD> </TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="10" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000"><B>Year Ended November</B></TD>
    <TD> </TD>

<HR size="1" width="12%" align="left" noshade color="#000000" style="margin-left: 5%">
<DIV align="right">
<TABLE width="95%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 8pt">

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left"><SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: top;">(1)</SUP></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="98%">Includes plan added in connection with business combination.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The firm&#146;s approach in determining
the long-term rate of return for plan assets is based upon
historical financial market relationships that have existed over
time with the presumption that this trend will generally remain
constant in the future.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">For measurement purposes, an annual
growth rate in the per capita cost of covered healthcare benefits
of 12.53% was assumed for the fiscal year ending November&nbsp;2005. The
rate was assumed to decrease ratably to 5.00% for the fiscal year
ending November&nbsp;2009 and remain at that level thereafter.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The assumed cost of healthcare has an
effect on the amounts reported for the firm&#146;s postretirement plans.
A 1% change in the assumed healthcare cost trend rate would have
the following effects:

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="90%">
<!-- Begin Table Head --><TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="52%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

    <TD> </TD>
    <TD> </TD>

    <TD> </TD>

    <TD> </TD>

</DIV>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The investment approach of the firm&#146;s
U.S. and major non-U.S.&nbsp;defined benefit pension plans involves
employing a sufficient level of flexibility to capture investment
opportunities as they occur, while maintaining reasonable
parameters to ensure that prudence and care are exercised in the
execution of the investment programs. The plans employ a total
return on investment approach, whereby a mix, which is broadly
similar to the actual asset allocation as of November&nbsp;2004, of
equity securities, debt securities and other assets is targeted to
maximize the long-term return on assets for a given level of risk.
Investment risk is measured and monitored on an ongoing basis by
the firm&#146;s Retirement Committee through periodic portfolio reviews,
meetings with investment managers and annual liability measurements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The firm will contribute a minimum of
$5&nbsp;million to its pension plans and $7&nbsp;million to its
postretirement plans in fiscal 2005.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The following table sets forth
benefits projected to be paid from the firm&#146;s U.S. and non-U.S.&nbsp;defined
benefit pension and postretirement plans and reflects
expected future service, where appropriate:

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-left: 2.5%"><B><I>Defined Contribution Plans</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The firm contributes to
employer-sponsored U.S. and non-U.S.&nbsp;defined contribution
plans. The firm&#146;s contribution to these plans was $189&nbsp;million,
$199&nbsp;million and $154&nbsp;million for the years ended November
2004, November&nbsp;2003 and November&nbsp;2002, respectively.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The firm maintained a nonqualified
defined contribution plan (the Plan) for certain senior employees.
Shares of common stock contributed to the Plan and outstanding as
of November&nbsp;2004 were 0.1&nbsp;million. Remaining shares were
distributed to participants and there were no remaining assets in
the plan as of January&nbsp;2005. Plan expense was immaterial for the
years ended November&nbsp;2004, November&nbsp;2003 and November&nbsp;
2002.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">128</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Arial,sans-serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE GOLDMAN SACHS GROUP, INC. and SUBSIDIARIES</B>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 10px"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left">
<A name="327"></A>
</DIV>
<!-- link1 "Note 12. Employee Incentive Plans" -->

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; background: transparent; color: #000000">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap width="5%"><B>Note&nbsp;12.</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="94%"><B>Employee Incentive Plans</B></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-left: 2.5%"><B><I>Stock Incentive Plan</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The firm sponsors a stock incentive
plan, The Goldman Sachs Amended and Restated Stock Incentive Plan
(the Amended SIP), which provides for grants of incentive stock
options, nonqualified stock options, stock appreciation rights,
dividend equivalent rights, restricted stock, restricted stock
units and other stock-based awards. In the second quarter of fiscal
2003, the Amended SIP was approved by the firm&#146;s shareholders,
effective for grants after April&nbsp;1, 2003, and no further awards
were or will be made under the original plan after that date,
although awards granted under the original plan prior to that date
remain outstanding.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The total number of shares of common
stock that may be issued under the Amended SIP through fiscal 2008
may not exceed 250&nbsp;million shares and, in each fiscal year
thereafter, may not exceed 5% of the issued and outstanding shares
of common stock, determined as of the last day of the immediately
preceding fiscal year, increased by the number of shares available
for awards in previous fiscal years but not covered by awards
granted in such years. As of November&nbsp;2004 and November&nbsp;2003, 218.9&nbsp;million
and 236.8&nbsp;million shares, respectively, were
available for grant under the Amended SIP, after taking into
account stock-based compensation awards that were issued subsequent
to year end, as part of year-end compensation.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-left: 2.5%"><B><I>Other Compensation Arrangements</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">In November&nbsp;2004, the firm adopted
new deferred compensation plans for eligible employees for fiscal
2005. In general, under the plans, participants will be able to
defer payment of a portion of their cash year-end compensation.
During the deferral period, participants will be able to nominally
invest their deferrals in certain alternatives available under the
plans. Generally, under current tax law, participants will not be
subject to income tax on amounts deferred or on any notional
investment earnings until the returns are distributed, and the firm
will not be entitled to a corresponding tax deduction until the
amounts are distributed.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">In November&nbsp;2004, the firm adopted a
discount stock program through which eligible senior executives may
acquire restricted stock units in fiscal 2005 under the firm&#146;s
Amended SIP at an effective 25% discount. The 25% discount is
effected by an additional grant of restricted stock units equal to
one-third of the number of restricted stock units purchased by
qualifying participants. The purchased restricted stock units will
be 100% vested when granted, but the shares underlying them will
not be able to be sold or transferred (other than to satisfy tax
obligations) before the third anniversary of the grant date. The
remaining shares underlying the restricted stock units will
generally vest in equal installments on the second and third
anniversaries following the grant date and will not be transferable
before the third anniversary of the grant date.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-left: 2.5%"><B><I>Restricted Stock Units</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The firm issued restricted stock
units to employees under the Amended SIP, primarily in connection
with year-end compensation and acquisitions. Of the total
restricted stock units outstanding as of November&nbsp;2004 and November
2003, (i)&nbsp;24.9&nbsp;million units and 24.5&nbsp;million units,
respectively, required future service as a condition to the
delivery of the underlying shares of common stock and (ii)&nbsp;13.0&nbsp;million
units and 23.3&nbsp;million units, respectively, did
not require future service.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">129</DIV>

<HR size="1" width="12%" align="left" noshade color="#000000" style="margin-left: 5%">
<DIV align="right">
<TABLE width="95%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 8pt">

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left"><SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: top;">(1)</SUP></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="98%">Includes restricted stock units granted to
employees subsequent to year end as part of year-end
compensation.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">Total employee stock compensation
expense, net of forfeitures, was $1.22&nbsp;billion, $711&nbsp;million
and $645&nbsp;million for the years ended November&nbsp;2004,
November&nbsp;2003 and November&nbsp;2002, respectively.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-left: 2.5%"><B><I>Stock Options</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">As of November&nbsp;2004, all stock
options granted to employees in May of 1999 in connection with the
firm&#146;s initial public offering are fully vested and exercisable.
Stock options granted to employees subsequent to the firm&#146;s initial
public offering generally vest as outlined in the applicable stock
option agreement and first become exercisable on the third
anniversary of the grant date. All employee stock option agreements
provide that vesting is accelerated in certain circumstances, such
as upon retirement, death and extended absence. In general, all
stock options expire on the tenth anniversary of the grant date,
although they may be subject to earlier termination or cancellation
in certain circumstances in accordance with the terms of the
Amended SIP and the applicable stock option agreement. The dilutive
effect of the firm&#146;s outstanding stock options is included in
&#147;Average common shares outstanding&nbsp;&#151; Diluted,&#148; in the
consolidated statements of earnings.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">130</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">Deferred income taxes reflect the net
tax effects of temporary differences between the financial
reporting and tax bases of assets and liabilities. These temporary
differences result in taxable or deductible amounts in future years
and are measured using the tax rates and laws that will be in
effect when such differences are expected to reverse.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">Significant components of the firm&#146;s
deferred tax assets and liabilities are set forth below:

<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="90%">
<!-- Begin Table Head --><TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="72%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="5%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="7%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<TR style="font-size: 8pt" valign="bottom">
    <TD> </TD>
    <TD> </TD>
    <TD nowrap align="center" colspan="6" style="border-bottom: 1px solid #000000"><B>As of November</B></TD>
    <TD> </TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left"><SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: top;">(1)</SUP></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="98%">Relates primarily to the ability to utilize
certain state and local and foreign tax credits.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The firm permanently reinvests
eligible earnings of certain foreign subsidiaries and, accordingly,
does not accrue any U.S.&nbsp;income taxes that would arise if such
earnings were repatriated. As of November&nbsp;2004, this policy
resulted in an unrecognized net deferred tax liability of $135&nbsp;million
attributable to reinvested earnings of $1.65&nbsp;billion.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">132</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE GOLDMAN SACHS GROUP, INC. and SUBSIDIARIES</B>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 10px"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</B>
</DIV>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">Additionally, during 2004, the
valuation allowance was increased by $3&nbsp;million, primarily due
to an increase in certain state and local tax credits. Acquired
federal net operating loss carryforwards of $88&nbsp;million as of
November&nbsp;2004 and $49&nbsp;million as of November&nbsp;2003 are subject
to annual limitations on utilization and will begin to expire in
2019. Acquired state and local net operating loss carryforwards of
$436&nbsp;million as of November&nbsp;2004 are subject to annual
limitations and will begin to expire in 2005. Acquired alternative
minimum tax credit carryforwards of $32&nbsp;million as of November&nbsp;2004
are subject to annual limitations on utilization, but can
be carried forward indefinitely.

in November&nbsp;2004, $103&nbsp;million in November&nbsp;2003
and $119&nbsp;million in November&nbsp;2002, related to the delivery of

<DIV align="left">
<A name="329"></A>
</DIV>
<!-- link1 "Note 14. Regulated Subsidiaries" -->

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; background: transparent; color: #000000">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap width="5%"><B>Note&nbsp;14.</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="94%"><B>Regulated Subsidiaries</B></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The firm&#146;s principal U.S. and
international regulated subsidiaries include Goldman, Sachs&nbsp;&#038;
Co. (GS&#038;Co.) and Goldman Sachs Execution&nbsp;&#038; Clearing, L.P.&nbsp;<SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: top;">(1)</SUP>
(GSEC)&nbsp;in New York, Goldman Sachs International (GSI)&nbsp;in
London and Goldman Sachs (Japan) Ltd. (GSJL)&nbsp;in Tokyo.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">GS&#038;Co. and GSEC are registered U.S.&nbsp;broker-dealers
and futures commission merchants subject to Rule&nbsp;15c3-1
of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC)&nbsp;and
Rule&nbsp;1.17 of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, which
specify uniform minimum net capital requirements, as defined, for
their registrants. They have elected to compute their net capital
in accordance with the &#147;Alternative Net Capital Requirement&#148; as
permitted by Rule&nbsp;15c3-1. As of November&nbsp;2004 and November
2003, GS&#038;Co. had regulatory net capital, as defined, of $5.92&nbsp;billion
and $3.66&nbsp;billion, respectively, which exceeded the
amounts required by $4.83&nbsp;billion and $2.82&nbsp;billion,
respectively. As of November&nbsp;2004 and November&nbsp;2003, GSEC had
regulatory net capital, as defined, of $1.05&nbsp;billion and $1.12&nbsp;billion,
respectively, which exceeded the amounts required by
$1.00&nbsp;billion and $1.08&nbsp;billion, respectively.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">GSI, a registered U.K. broker-dealer,
is subject to the capital requirements of the Financial Services
Authority, and GSJL, a Tokyo-based broker-dealer, is subject to the
capital requirements of the Financial Services Agency. As of
November&nbsp;2004 and November&nbsp;2003, GSI and GSJL were in compliance
with their local capital adequacy requirements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">Certain other subsidiaries of the
firm are also subject to capital adequacy requirements promulgated
by authorities of the countries in which they operate. As of
November&nbsp;2004 and


<P>
<HR size="1" width="12%" align="left" noshade color="#000000" style="margin-left: 0%">
<DIV align="right">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 8pt">

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left"><SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: top;">(1)</SUP></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="98%">The firm renamed Spear, Leeds &#038; Kellogg, L.P., Goldman Sachs Execution &#038; Clearing, L.P., effective January&nbsp;14, 2005.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">133</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Arial,sans-serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE GOLDMAN SACHS GROUP, INC. and SUBSIDIARIES</B>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 10px"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</B>
</DIV>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt">November&nbsp;2003, these subsidiaries were in
compliance with their local capital adequacy requirements.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The SEC has adopted rule amendments
that establish alternative net capital requirements for
broker-dealers that are part of a consolidated supervised entity.
As a condition to its use of the alternative method, a
broker-dealer&#146;s ultimate holding company and affiliates (referred
to collectively as a consolidated supervised entity or CSE) must
consent to group-wide supervision and examination by the SEC.
GS&#038;Co. anticipates applying for permission to use this alternative
method. The firm expects that doing so will enable it to comply
with the requirements of the Financial Groups Directive (Directive
2002/87/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council, relating
to the regulation in Europe of financial services organizations).
On becoming subject to the SEC&#146;s group-wide supervision, the firm
will be required to report to the SEC computations of the firm&#146;s
capital adequacy.

<DIV align="left">
<A name="330"></A>
</DIV>
<!-- link1 "Note 15. Business Segments" -->

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; background: transparent; color: #000000">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap width="5%"><B>Note&nbsp;15.</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="94%"><B>Business Segments</B></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">In reporting to management, the
firm&#146;s operating results are categorized into the following three
segments: Investment Banking, Trading and Principal Investments,
and Asset Management and Securities Services.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The firm made certain changes to its
segment reporting structure in 2003. These changes included
reclassifying the following from Asset Management and Securities
Services to Trading and Principal Investments:


<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="5%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&#149;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>equity commissions and clearing and execution fees;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="5%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&#149;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>merchant banking overrides;&nbsp;and</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="5%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&#149;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>the matched book businesses.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">These reclassifications did not
affect the firm&#146;s historical consolidated results of operations,
financial condition or cash flows. Certain reclassifications have
been made to previously reported amounts to conform to the current
presentation.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-left: 2.5%"><B><I>Basis of Presentation</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">In reporting segments, certain of the
firm&#146;s business lines have been aggregated where they have similar
economic characteristics and are similar in each of the following
areas: (i)&nbsp;the nature of the services they provide, (ii)&nbsp;their
methods of distribution, (iii)&nbsp;the types of clients they
serve and (iv)&nbsp;the regulatory environments in which they
operate.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The cost drivers of the firm taken as
a whole&nbsp;&#151; compensation, headcount and levels of business
activity&nbsp;&#151; are broadly similar in each of the firm&#146;s business
segments. Compensation expenses within the firm&#146;s segments reflect,
among other factors, the overall performance of the firm as well as
performance of individual business units. Consequently, pre-tax
margins in one segment of the firm&#146;s business may be significantly
affected by the performance of the firm&#146;s other business segments.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The firm allocates revenues and
expenses among the three segments. Due to the integrated nature of
the business segments, estimates and judgments have been made in
allocating certain revenue and expense items. Transactions between
segments are based on specific criteria or approximate third-party
rates. Total operating expenses include corporate items that have
not been allocated to individual business segments. The allocation
process is based on the manner in which management views the
business of the firm.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">134</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Arial,sans-serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE GOLDMAN SACHS GROUP, INC. and SUBSIDIARIES</B>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 10px"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</B>
</DIV>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The segment information presented in
the table below is prepared according to the following
methodologies:


<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">
<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="5%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&#149;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Revenues and expenses directly associated with each segment are included in
determining pre-tax earnings.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="5%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&#149;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Net revenues in the firm&#146;s segments include allocations of interest income and
interest expense to specific securities, commodities and other positions in relation
to the cash generated by, or funding requirements of, such underlying positions. Net
interest is included within segment net revenues as it is consistent with the way in
which management assesses segment performance.</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="5">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="5%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left">&#149;</TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Overhead expenses not directly allocable to specific segments are allocated
ratably based on direct segment expenses.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">135</DIV>

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Arial,sans-serif">

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>THE GOLDMAN SACHS GROUP, INC. and SUBSIDIARIES</B>

<DIV align="center" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 10px"><B>NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS (Continued)</B>
</DIV>

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-left: 2.5%"><B><I>Geographic Information</I></B>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">Due to the highly integrated nature
of international financial markets, the firm manages its businesses
based on the profitability of the enterprise as a whole.
Accordingly, management believes that profitability by geographic
region is not necessarily meaningful.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The firm&#146;s revenues, expenses and
identifiable assets are generally allocated based on the country of
domicile of the legal entity providing the service.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The following table sets forth the
total net revenues, pre-tax earnings and identifiable assets of the
firm and its consolidated subsidiaries by geographic region
allocated on the basis described above:

<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="90%">

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left"><SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: top;">(1)</SUP></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="98%">Includes the following expenses that have not
been allocated to the firm&#146;s segments: (i)&nbsp;the
amortization of employee initial public offering awards,
net of forfeitures, of $19&nbsp;million, $80&nbsp;million
and $212&nbsp;million for the years ended November&nbsp;2004,
November&nbsp;2003 and November&nbsp;2002, respectively, (ii)&nbsp;net
provisions for a number of litigation and regulatory
proceedings of $103&nbsp;million and $155&nbsp;million for
the years ended November&nbsp;2004 and November&nbsp;2003,
respectively, and (iii)&nbsp;$62&nbsp;million in
connection with the establishment of Goldman Sachs Gao
Hua Securities Company Limited, an investment banking and
securities venture in China, for the year ended November
2004.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 4pt">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>

not allocable to a particular geographic region.</TD>

<!-- link1 "SUPPLEMENTAL FINANCIAL INFORMATION" -->

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>SUPPLEMENTAL FINANCIAL INFORMATION</B>

<DIV align="left">
<A name="332"></A>
</DIV>
<!-- link1 "Quarterly Results (unaudited)" -->

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>Quarterly Results (unaudited)</B>



<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">The following represents the firm&#146;s
unaudited quarterly results for fiscal 2004 and fiscal 2003. These
quarterly results were prepared in accordance with U.S.&nbsp;generally
accepted accounting principles and reflect all
adjustments that are, in the opinion of management, necessary for a
fair statement of the results. These adjustments are of a normal
recurring nature.

<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">As of January&nbsp;28, 2005, there
were approximately 5,660&nbsp;holders of record of the firm&#146;s common
stock.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">On January&nbsp;28, 2005, the last
reported sales price for the firm&#146;s common stock on the New York
Stock Exchange was $106.12 per share.

<!-- link1 "Item&nbsp;9. Changes in and Disagreements With Accountants on Accounting and Financial DisclosureThere were no changes in or disagreements with accountants on accounting and financial disclosure during the last two fiscal years." -->

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; background: transparent; color: #000000">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap width="5%"><B>Item&nbsp;9.</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="94%"><B>Changes in and Disagreements With Accountants on Accounting and Financial Disclosure</B></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">There were no changes in or
disagreements with accountants on accounting and financial
disclosure during the last two fiscal years.

<DIV align="left">
<A name="111"></A>
</DIV>
<!-- link1 "Item&nbsp;9A. Controls and Procedures" -->

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; background: transparent; color: #000000">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap width="5%"><B>Item&nbsp;9A.</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="94%"><B>Controls and Procedures</B></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">As of the end of the period covered
by this report, an evaluation was carried out by Goldman Sachs&#146;
management, with the participation of our Chief Executive Officer
and Chief Financial Officer, of the effectiveness of our disclosure
controls and procedures (as defined in Rule&nbsp;13a-15(e) under the
Securities Exchange Act of 1934). Based upon that evaluation, our
Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer concluded that
these disclosure controls and procedures were effective as of the
end of the period covered by this report. In addition, no change in
our internal control over financial reporting (as defined in Rule&nbsp;13a-15(f)
under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934) occurred
during the fourth quarter of our fiscal year ended November&nbsp;26,
2004 that has materially affected, or is reasonably likely to
materially affect, our internal control over financial reporting.


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">Management&#146;s Report on Internal
Control over Financial Reporting and the Report of Independent
Registered Public Accounting Firm thereon are set forth in Part&nbsp;II,
Item&nbsp;8 of the Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">141</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Arial,sans-serif">
<DIV align="left">
<A name="150"></A>
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><B>PART&nbsp;III</B>

<DIV align="left">
<A name="112"></A>
</DIV>
<!-- link1 "Item&nbsp;10. Directors and Executive Officers of the Registrant" -->

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; background: transparent; color: #000000">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap width="5%"><B>Item&nbsp;10.</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="94%"><B>Directors and Executive Officers of the Registrant</B></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">Information relating to the
Registrant&#146;s executive officers is included on pages&nbsp;38 to 39
of the Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K. Information relating to
directors of the Registrant, including its audit committee and
audit committee financial experts, and its executive officers will
be in the definitive Proxy Statement for its 2005 Annual Meeting of
Shareholders to be held on April&nbsp;6, 2005, which will be filed
within 120&nbsp;days of the end of our fiscal year ended November&nbsp;26,
2004 (the 2005 Proxy Statement) and is incorporated herein
by reference. Information relating to the Registrant&#146;s Code of
Business Conduct and Ethics that applies to its senior financial
officers, as defined in the Code, is included in Part&nbsp;I, Item&nbsp;1
of the Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K.

<DIV align="left">
<A name="113"></A>
</DIV>
<!-- link1 "Item&nbsp;11. Executive Compensation" -->

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; background: transparent; color: #000000">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap width="5%"><B>Item&nbsp;11.</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="94%"><B>Executive Compensation</B></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">Information relating to the
Registrant&#146;s executive officer and director compensation will be in
the 2005 Proxy Statement and is incorporated herein by reference.

<DIV align="left">
<A name="114"></A>
</DIV>
<!-- link1 "Item&nbsp;12. Security Ownership of Certain Beneficial Owners and Management and Related Stockholder Matters" -->

<P>
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt; background: transparent; color: #000000">
<TR valign="top">
    <TD nowrap width="5%"><B>Item&nbsp;12.</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="94%"><B>Security Ownership of Certain Beneficial Owners and Management and Related Stockholder Matters</B></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>


<P align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; text-indent: 5%">Information relating to security
ownership of certain beneficial owners of the Registrant&#146;s common
stock and information relating to the security ownership of the
Registrant&#146;s management will be in the 2005 Proxy Statement and is
incorporated herein by reference.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">142</DIV>

granted on December&nbsp;14, 2004 in respect of fiscal 2004
performance as part of the firm&#146;s Discount Stock Program.

<HR size="1" width="12%" align="left" noshade color="#000000" style="margin-left: 5%">
<DIV align="right">
<TABLE width="95%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 8pt">

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left"><SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: top;">(1)</SUP></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="98%">The Goldman Sachs Amended and Restated Stock
Incentive Plan (the SIP) was approved by the shareholders
of Goldman Sachs at our 2003 Annual Meeting of
Shareholders and is a successor plan to The Goldman Sachs
1999 Stock Incentive Plan, which was approved by our
shareholders immediately prior to our initial public
offering in May&nbsp;1999 and under which no additional
awards have been granted since approval of the SIP.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 4pt">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left"><SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: top;">(2)</SUP></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="98%">The number of securities to be issued upon
exercise of outstanding options, warrants and rights, as
well as the weighted average exercise price of the
outstanding options, warrants and rights, excludes
approximately 120,000 options granted with a strike price
of $0.01 or less in foreign jurisdictions that were
intended to replicate the economic effect of our
restricted stock units.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 4pt">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left"><SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: top;">(3)</SUP></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="98%">Of the 257,383,307&nbsp;shares remaining available
for future issuance under the SIP (including shares that
may be delivered in the future under existing awards),
41,027,946 of these shares may be issued pursuant to
outstanding restricted stock units.</TD>
</TR>

<TR style="font-size: 4pt">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD width="1%" nowrap align="left"><SUP style="font-size: 85%; vertical-align: top;">(4)</SUP></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="98%">The total number of shares of common stock that
may be delivered pursuant to awards granted under the SIP
initially may not exceed 250,000,000&nbsp;shares.
Beginning November&nbsp;29, 2008 and each fiscal year
thereafter, the number of shares of common stock that may
be delivered pursuant to awards granted after April&nbsp;
1, 2003 under the SIP may not exceed 5% of our issued and
outstanding shares of common stock, determined as of the
last day of the immediately preceding fiscal year,
increased by the number of shares available for awards in
previous fiscal years but not then covered by awards
granted in such years.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

SUPPLEMENTAL DISCLOSURES:<BR>
<FONT style="font-size:4pt">&nbsp;</FONT><BR>
Cash payments for interest, net of capitalized interest, were $2.59&nbsp;billion, $1.97&nbsp;billion
and $2.21&nbsp;billion for the years ended November&nbsp;2004, November&nbsp;2003 and November&nbsp;2002,
respectively.<BR>
<FONT style="font-size:4pt">&nbsp;</FONT><BR>
Cash payments for income taxes, net of refunds, were $284&nbsp;million, $324&nbsp;million and
$546&nbsp;million for the years ended November&nbsp;2004, November&nbsp;2003 and November&nbsp;2002, respectively.<BR>
<FONT style="font-size:4pt">&nbsp;</FONT><BR>
<I>Noncash activities:</I><BR>
<FONT style="font-size:4pt">&nbsp;</FONT><BR>
The value of common stock issued in connection with business combinations was $165&nbsp;million
and $47&nbsp;million for the years ended November&nbsp;2003 and November&nbsp;2002, respectively.<BR>
<FONT style="font-size:4pt">&nbsp;</FONT><BR>
Stock-based compensation expense included in subsidiary net earnings was $1.10&nbsp;billion,
$644&nbsp;million and $609&nbsp;million for the years ended November&nbsp;2004, November&nbsp;2003 and
November&nbsp;2002, respectively.</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">The accompanying notes are an integral part of these condensed nonconsolidated financial statements.


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt">F-4</DIV>
